At 0:58 OFNF claims that endogenous retroviruses (ERVs) do not support evolution. He also states that Talk Origins misrepresents the “facts”. Throughout this video he constantly refers to the facts however he never makes it quite clear what facts he is talking about. From 1:00 to 2:06, AbusiveAntiTheist (AAT) explains what ERVs are and explains that the animals we are closely related to share more of the same ERVs than animals we are not closely related to. OFNF then concedes that AAT’s explanation would be reasonable if evolution were true. Obviously, OFNF does not consider evolution true. Keep in mind that the explanation AAT gave in this video is an explanation showing that organisms that are closely related will have more similarities than organisms that are less related. Also, keep in mind how vague the notion that “many similarities between organisms indicate that they are closely related while fewer similarities between animals indicate that they are less closely related” is. Though this notion is a very, very, very rudimentary notion used in regards to evolution, it is not specific as the more complicated reasoning behind the theory of evolution. OFNF attacks this extremely vague notion and uses his criticism of the notion to attack the whole theory of evolution. This is a clear example of straw-manning a position if there ever was one. This will be made clear later on. At 3:30 he makes a distinction between the facts and the interpretation of the facts. He concedes that there are many similarities between organisms at 3:36. However, he does not concede that the fact that animals have similarities implies that animals who share many similarities are closely related. In fact, he states that such an assumption is merely an interpretation of the fact that organisms possess many similarities. He seems to believe that the phylogenetic tree is based solely on the vague assumption that the more similarities that animals have then the more they are related while the less similarities animals have between each other indicates that they are less related. However, he never elaborates on what he means by “similarities” and he never elaborates on what specific animals he is talking about until later on. Well, he sort of elaborates later on. He also claims that “evolutionists” only teach one side of the story as if there is some sort of valid alternative to evolution in the discipline of biology. He also claims that “evolutionists” go through great lengths to ban the controversy regarding evolution from being taught in the class room. He also states that evolutionists ignore contrary evidence while keeping contrary evidence out of the class room. He again states that the “facts” state otherwise. At this point this is where we sort of get into the details. OFNF goes on to cite an article titled “Rewriting Evolution: Tiny molecules called microRNAs are tearing apart traditional ideas about the animal family tree.” as an example of “evolutionists” ignoring contrary evidence. Humorously, he highlights the part of the title that states that microRNA is changing the order of the family tree of evolution yet ignores that the title implies that evolution will still be true being that the title says that evolution is being rewritten and not being shown to be false. He then quotes a part of the article which includes molecular paleobiologist at Dartmouth College, Kevin Peterson’s own words.   “’I’ve looked at thousands of microRNA genes, and I can’t find a single example that would support the traditional tree,” he says. The technique “just changes everything about our understanding of mammal evolution’.”   Here we see another sign of the inconsistency of OFNF’s reasoning. Earlier in the video he stated that evolutionists ignore contrary evidence to evolution yet OFNF cites Peterson (someone he considers an evolutionist) that deals directly with evidence that OFNF considers contrary to evolution. The rest of the article cites other evolutionists who are not ignoring what OFNF considers contrary evidence. This is a tad bit hilarious. He claims that evolutionists are ignoring contrary evidence yet cites a whole article of “evolutionists” not ignoring the very data that OFNF feels is contrary to evolution.  Even funnier is that nothing in the article is contrary to evolution. The article states that Peterson’s findings are contrary to the traditional evolutionary branches on the evolutionary tree yet Peterson’s evidence still supports an evolutionary tree. For example, the article OFNF cites shows a picture of a side-by-side comparison of the traditional evolutionary tree of placental mammals and Kevin Peterson’s evolutionary tree of placental mammals on the PDF of the article. What OFNF fails to communicate is that the two different branches in the side-by-side comparison still show that placental mammals are still a closely related family on their own branch no matter which branch is correct on this side-by-side comparison. Essentially, it is the order and placement of twigs on the branch that is in question. It is not evolution that is in question. Peterson’s evidence is still in support of evolution. OFNF’s claim that there is controversy within the biological community is overstated. If anything the article is great news because it shows that we are improving our understanding of biological evolution. If Peterson is right then we will only make the theory of evolution a stronger theory. If Peterson is wrong then it still makes the theory of evolution a stronger theory. It is a win-win situation being that Peterson’s evidence supports evolution anyways. However, Peterson’s data has not yet been confirmed as the article states.   At 5:06 OFNF continues on to state that in order to get published in peer-reviewed scientific journals one’s results have to line up with the theory of evolution regardless if your data is irrefutable. According to OFNF, if your data doesn’t line up with evolution then your work doesn’t get published and people will have a bias against you. OFNF then supports his assertion by quote mining the article at 5:21. Quote:   “At first, Peterson and Sempere had a tough time publishing their results suggesting that animals had accumulated regulatory microRNAs. ‘One of the reviewers said it was impossible, what we were describing,’ says Peterson.”   OFNF seems to gloss over the two sentences right after the quote he cites that states that Peterson’s papers were eventually published.   “In the end, the work was published in a specialized zoology journal. Subsequent papers, however, won over some sceptics and Peterson was soon publishing in Nature and Science”   Keep in mind that Nature and Science are very prestigious and mainstream science journals that did not ignore Peterson’s findings.   Furthermore, Peterson’s papers were not initially rejected because his data did not align with the theory of evolution. His data was rejected because it was brand new data that has never been seen at the time, period. This is how science works. New data must survive tons of scrutiny before getting published so as to maintain a high standard within the discipline. Sometimes new data gets rejected a few times when going through the peer-review process before finally gaining acceptance. The peer-review process is exactly how Newton and Einstein’s findings gained acceptance. Their findings were scrutinized and sometimes rejected but soon gained acceptance. Peterson’s findings gained acceptance the same way. OFNF then states that creationists have their own scientific journals because of this alleged bias. However, it is clear that OFNF is wrong. He then quotes the same article but only quotes those that disagree with Peterson’s findings. OFNF does not show you the quotes that show that not everyone in the same field as Peterson disagrees with Peterson. After all, Peterson would not have been able to get published if no one agreed with him. Nonetheless, here’s a quote from the same article OFNF quote mines that shows that others agree with Peterson’s microRNA findings:    “That has won him many critics, but also some strong supporters. ‘Peterson and his col­leagues have demonstrated that microRNAs are a powerful tool in determining the rela­tionships of major animal groups,’ says Derek Briggs, director of the Yale Peabody Museum of Natural History in New Haven, Connecticut.”       Elsewhere in the article, evolutionary bioinformatician, Peter Stadler agrees:   “‘It is a really clever and fresh approach to phylogeny,’ says Peter Stadler, an evolutionary bioinformatician at the University of Leipzig in Germany. ‘I don’t quite know why pres­ence/absence of microRNAs is not used more frequently in deep phylogeny approaches.’”   It is clear that scientists are divided on this matter and it is clear that the matter is a work in progress as the article indicates.   OFNF then quotes an abstract of a paper entitled the “Gene tree discordance, phylogenetic inference and the multispecies coalescent”. This is a sophomore move from OFNF. A simple Wikipedia search will show that abstracts are very limited and that the full article should be consulted. Consulting an abstract alone is inadequate when trying to get the full picture. Based on what OFNF quoted from the abstract, Wikipedia is actually right. What OFNF forgiven quoted from the abstract is not very specific at all. At 6:48 OFNF quotes from the abstract stating:   “…conflicting genealogical histories often exist in different genes throughout the genome…resolving close species relationships is not quite as simple as applying more data to the problem.”   From these two statements and a small quote from the article OFNF claims that the article shows genetic trees are different depending on what set of genetic data one looks at but he does not elaborate to what extent the trees are changed. Is the entire evolutionary tree different such that bees fall on a twig on the evolutionary branch of placental mammals or are the differences in genetic trees minor such that tiny twigs of closely related species fall on different places of slightly bigger twig but still strongly support the theory of evolution? OFNF never elaborates on this. However, the abstract OFNF quotes states that resolving [close] species relationships is not simple which indicates that the major branches on the evolutionary tree are well confirmed but it is the minute details of the twigs on this tree which needs further investigation and refining. In other words, the evolutionary tree has been demonstrated. At 8:10, OFNF cites the paper titled “Mapping Human Genetic Ancestry” (http://mbe.oxfordjournals.org/content/24/10/2266.full.pdf+html), and uses the paper to argue against evolution. The paper does state that human evolution is not entirely certain but the paper does state that human evolution did occur. It is also certain that the great apes are closely related and share a common ancestor as is shown in table 2 and 3 of the paper. The paper also doesn’t ignore the incongruent data. The paper actually addresses the data directly and admits to the incongruent data though OFNF ignores that while once again falsely claiming that contrary data is ignored. It seems like it is OFNF that is ignoring the data. OFNF also states that phylogenetic trees cannot be used to prove the family tree but he fails to realize that they are one in the same. He also fails to realize that the family tree cannot be proven because new data can always turn up which could change current phylogeny (http://evolution.berkeley.edu/evolibrary/article/phylogenetics_05). In fact, no science is ever proven exactly because new data can always change current scientific knowledge. All scientific theories are tentative so it is nonsensical for OFNF to ask for the family tree to be proven. The evolutionary tree has already been demonstrated anyways. At 9:38 OFNF quotes the article with Kevin Peterson once again and asserts that AAT is only paying attention to what conforms to AAT’s supposedly preconceived notion that the theory of evolution is correct a priori. However, I have already shown how OFNF has grossly misrepresented the article which renders his charge against ATT superfluous. OFNF then moves on to talk about ERVs but OFNF doesn’t just talk about ERVs, he grossly misrepresents what ERVs tell us about evolution. OFNF argues that it is very likely that chimps and humans would share identical ERV sites while still acquiring ERV cites independently because there are so many cites (~30,000) in human DNA and ERV cites do not occur in random spots. Even granting OFNFs constraints, his argument still does not explain why only specific species share the same exact ERV cites that others do not. For instance, the HERV-K insertion is only shared among various primates. Also, small cats (e.g. the jungle cat, European wildcat, African wildcat, blackfooted cat, and domestic cat) under the family Felidae all share a specific retrogene insertion not found in any other carnivore. Is OFNF going to argue that the matching EVR insertions that are exclusive to primates occurred independently for each primate species but match up perfectly by coincidence? How about the ERV insertion that small cats in the Felidae family share? Did that insertion occur independently of every species in that group but just happens to match up perfectly while that same insertion is completely absent from all other animals? I think not. Clearly, he is just trying to discredit evolution even if his objections make no sense. Given that ERVs are only passed down to descendants it is clear that animals that share ERVs are related and small groups of different species that exclusively share ERVs all share common ancestry. Basically, ERVs do support evolution despite OFNF’s objections in this video. +Ahmad1342 READ IT AND WEEP BIGOTS!    http://theconversation.com/african-scientists-recognise-that-diverse-sexuality-is-the-norm-43050  The Academy of Science in South Africa (ASSAf), in collaboration with the Uganda National Academy of Sciences, has just released a comprehensive “consensus report” on human sexual diversity.  This is a significant contribution in a continent in which gay relationships are criminalised in 38 out of 55 countries, four of which impose the death penalty.  The study used a panel of non-partisan volunteer experts to assess the considerable and often contradictory literature on biological, social and environmental factors in sexual diversity. It is one of the most clear-sighted evaluations that I have encountered, and it deserves to be taken very seriously in Africa and elsewhere.  A range of sexuality  The nub of the report is its conclusion that diversity in human sexuality is:  … a range of human variation, very little of which can justifiably be termed abnormal. The source of this variation has been contentious for decades, despite the accumulating evidence that nature (“born gay”) is overwhelmingly more significant than nurture (“lifestyle choice”).  The report has a large and readable section on biological factors in homosexuality, including neurohormone effects on the fetus, and “epigenetic” influence on the activity of genes by chemical modifications that can be modified by the environment and are transmitted to all the cells of the individual, and sometimes even between generations.  As the report summarises, family studies over decades show that gay men are more likely than average to have gay brothers, and lesbian women more likely to have lesbian sisters.  Many twin studies showing that identical twins are twice as likely as non-identical twins to be concordant (both straight or both gay) imply a clear genetic component, but the 70% concordance leaves room for considerable non-genetic effect. This is true whether or not the twins were raised together.  A 1993 report of a gay gene on the X chromosome has been recently confirmed by a larger study, with the addition of another one or two gay genes. Illustration of Serge and Bacchus, in a same-sex union  John Boswell was a historian and religious Catholic who dedicated much of his scholarly life to studying the late Roman Empire and early Christian Church. Poring over legal and church documents from this era, he discovered something incredible. There were dozens of records of church ceremonies where two men were joined in unions that used the same rituals as heterosexual marriages. (He found almost no records of lesbian unions, which is probably an artifact of a culture which kept more records about the lives of men generally.)  Bolstered by this evidence, Boswell published a book in 1994, the year before his death from AIDS, called Same-Sex Unions in Pre-Modern Europe. The book comes out next month for the first time in a digital edition. It was an instant lightening rod for controversy, drawing criticism from both the Catholic Church and sex pundit Camille Paglia. Given the Church's present-day views on gay marriage, these detractors argued, Boswell's history seemed like wishful thinking.     But it wasn't. Boswell had actually begun his research back in the 1970s, and published an equally controversial work in 1980 called Christianity, Social Tolerance, and Homosexuality: Gay People in Western Europe from the Beginning of the Christian Era to the Fourteenth Century. His Same-Sex Unions book refined and expanded a lot of what he'd learned over a lifetime of research into primary sources in scattered libraries and archives.    How could these marriages have been forgotten by history? One easy answer is that — as Boswell argues — the Church reframed the idea of marriage in the 13th century to be for the purposes of procreation. And this slammed the door on gay marriage. Church scholars and officials worked hard to suppress the history of these marriages in order to justify their new definition.  Of course, history is more complicated than that. Boswell claims that part of the problem is that we define marriage so differently today that it's almost impossible for historians to recognize 1800-year-old gay marriage documents when they see them. Often, these documents refer to uniting "brothers," which at the time would have been a way of describing same-sex partners whose lifestyles were tolerated in Rome. Also, marriages over a millennium ago were not based on procreation, but wealth-sharing. So "marriage" sometimes meant a non-sexual union of two people's or families' wealth. Boswell admits that some of the documents he found may refer simply to non-sexual joining of two men's fortunes — but many also referred to what today we would call gay marriage.  Gay marriage in the year 100 AD Legal scholar Richard Ante wrote a law journal article explaining that Boswell's book could even be used as evidence for the legality of gay marriage, since it shows evidence that definitions of marriage have changed over time. He describes some of Boswell's evidence of these same-sex rites in the early first millennium:  The burial rite given for Achilles and Patroclus, both men, was the burial rite for a man and his wife. The relationships of Hadrian and Antinous, of Polyeuct and Nearchos, of Perpetua and Felicitas, and of Saints Serge and Bacchus, all bore resemblance to heterosexual marriages of their times. The iconography of Serge and Bacchus was even used in same-sex nuptial ceremonies by the early Christian Church. The main piece of evidence that these same-sex unions were marriages is that they so closely resembled heterosexual ceremonies. Literary scholar Bruce Holsinger describes Boswell's detailed stories of same-sex ceremonies:  [Boswell] cleverly posits the development of heterosexual and same-sex nuptial offices as a single phenomenon, tracking the growth of the latter from "merely a set of prayers " in the earlier Middle Ages to its flowering as a "full office" by the twelfth century that involved "the burning of candles, the placing of the two parties' hands on the Gospel, the joining of their right hands, the binding of their hands . . . with the priest's stole, an introductory litany crowning, the Lord's Prayer, Communion, a kiss, and sometimes circling around the altar." Boswell devotes a full chapter to comparing these rituals with their heterosexual counterparts, revealing a number of extraordinary similarities between the two; in several appendixes totaling almost 100 pages, he has compiled numerous examples of the documents themselves (including heterosexual matrimony ceremonies and adoption rituals for comparison) to let "readers . . . judge for themselves," as he puts it. (Boswell translates most of the ceremonies, so general readers won't have to worry about brushing up on their Old Church Slavonic.) Were these same-sex unions in the middle ages the same thing as today's gay marriages? Probably not. People at the time may not have viewed two men forming a union as anything out of the ordinary. Marriage itself meant something different thousands of years ago, and social taboos against homosexuality had not yet solidified. Still, in Boswell's work, we find records of institutions where same-sex couples were honored with the same ceremonies that opposite-sex couples enjoyed. Two men could live as "brothers," sharing wealth, home, and family. And yes, they could love each other, too.  Though Boswell died before his country began to allow similar kinds of unions, he could draw hope from knowing something that most people did not. Even the most fundamental kinds of human relationships change over time. Those who have been banished today may be blessed tomorrow — just as they were over a thousand years ago.

I'm personally only interested in the effects on adults, since effects on children isn't something with destructive implications like banning the game. It just means, paying attention (or heightening) age restrictions. And I suppose the average gamer who play's such content is least above 16 years. I hope so. *_*  I would make a strong distinction between findings of effects on children and adults since both have completely different implications.  __Now just a general take on science and video games__  There is a difference between short term and long term effects. Many (often experimental) studies in terms of video game violence only look at short term effects(1). Another problem is that they often use two different, self selected groups of people and check them individually. Not what effect has X on the same people. Who will the same people think after watching this? And how long does that effect last? Are there things (like watching other content afterwards, or going shopping, making sports, eating, reading, the next morning etc. - normal things many of us do) that moderate or reverse that effect?  I think the best studies would be longitudinal studies that go over 1 year or 2, like this German one about sexism(2) that found no link between sexism (first order effects) and video game usage.  My problem with (short term) experimental study results are: Let's make something up, let's say, you let me play a video game and I'm 10% more aggressive than before after doing so... this effect HAS TO reverse, decay, or be inconsistent! Otherwise every time I would play a violent video game this effect would happen. Every time a 10% increase in aggression. At some point my aggression level would be at 1000%! This is stupid! And let's say I have played violent video games before this test... let's say 20 times. Wouldn't I already be 200% more aggressive than before playing them? And I'm, like most other people not an friggin' angel. Most people have a certain degree of violent aggression within them, especially when they're young. So a 200% increase would be rather astronomical. That's why a "you are 10% more aggressive result" wouldn't bother me very much. Because it MUST decrease to some extent. Otherwise everyone who plays violent video games daily, for 1 year would be 3600% more aggressive than when they started. Stupid.  Same with sexism. If every time I watched "sexist" content my tolerance of sexual harassment, as claimed here(3) would increase, at some point I would be cheering and celebrating sexual harassment, or just not care at all.  I have watched lot's of content in the past, that joy kills would call sexist.objectification.demeaning.exploitation.blup content and I took the little harassment survey of this study(3) and was very harsh with the Mr. Grabbers in this story. So when does my effect kick in? If "sexist" content I watched in the past increased  And if my effect got reversed or moderated by my awareness that there is a possibility that media influences my judgement of such things, then a simple semi-fix would be informing people. Viewers discretion advised.   Another problem is that experimental studies that show effects which aren't truly strong (like with most "media washes your brain studies"), is that they often aren't very repeatable(4). When repeated, the follow up experiments often reveal weaker effects than the original study. And "media washes your brain" stuff is most definitely AT LEAST ambiguous.(5)    And let's not forget publication bias.(6) For my taste there are far to little published psychological/experimental studies in the field of video game influence. So it could be that many studies were conducted and most didn't find a significant effect and therefore didn't get published. I suspect most Journals are more interested in such effects, because that means further implications. While non-significant/negative results just mean - it's all fine for gamer's!
